The parents said:

Before they finished speaking, the dead person suddenly opened his eyes.
The parents and all the people in the village were overjoyed, but unable to move him, they all guarded him together.
On the tenth day, he was able to sit up and speak well.
The people asked where he had been and what he had seen.

There is a king in the prison who asks me,

He then gave me a seat, and I sat down.
The king then called the officials and asked them,
This is a disciple of the unsurpassed, true, and correct one. You all should be saved by this person. He will only die when his life is exhausted!
When his soul follows his actions and receives rebirth, if he is born in the heavens, the celestial spirits will come to welcome him;

How can you bring this venerable person to this place of the five heinous crimes?
The officials replied to the king,

In the world, there are many such people who do not fear the king's laws, do not fear the four seasons and five phases, are not bound by ghosts and spirits, and are not recorded by heaven and earth. Can we not ask about one or two of them?

The king said:

The official reported to the king, saying:

The king said:
If a person lives in the world for a hundred years, committing few evil deeds, what will be the punishment for such a person?
The officer said:
This person can only be born and cannot die. After death, he will continue to receive painful punishments for thousands and myriads of kalpas without liberation.
At that time, the king said:
The Buddha's disciples who have precepts, diligently practice without laziness, are respected by the celestial spirits.

The reason is that the Buddha, with a mind of great compassion and great pity, and a mind of dedication, with these four equal minds, worries about the people of the ten directions, all people, myriad things, and the crawling and flying creatures. The Buddha has compassion for them all, and his merits and virtues flow to the people of the ten directions.

Therefore, the Buddha's disciples, celestial spirits, earth deities, ghosts, and dragons all respect and honor them. How could they be bound by the king's appearance, the four seasons, or the five elements?
The Buddha's grace is like the four seas, immeasurable. The Ganges River has billions of sand grains, which can be weighed and measured to know their number, but the Buddha's grace is beyond measure.
The officer said to the king:
'Does the great king uphold the pure precepts of the Buddha?'
The king said:
'Because I did not uphold the Buddha, I was pursued and punished, becoming the king of this hell.

You see that in this hell, there are now some whose lives have ended but who have not yet received [their punishment]. They dare not come forward, but all will join their palms, rise, and go to welcome them. Let them examine the good blessings they have practiced, and the gods of blessings will come to welcome them.
Those whose lives are not yet to end have their own protection and will quickly be cured.

If someone has already entered the true Dharma, but later regrets it and returns to being a non-Buddhist, killing and sacrificing, the evil ghosts of the wrong path will find an opportunity in them. This is because they have no protection for themselves.
Even if they have a lifespan of a thousand years, they will encounter the nine calamities and die an untimely death.
The reason for this is that the protective deities will not support them, and in this way they will never attain liberation.
If a monk who upholds the precepts and his disciples, they should diligently practice six things.
What are the six?
First, the perfection of giving, one should be generous and not be stingy;
Second, the perfection of morality, one should guard the precepts and not violate them;
Third, the perfection of patience, one should be tolerant and subdue one's mind, not giving rise to anger with one's mouth;
Fourth, the perfection of vigor, one should be diligent and not lazy;
Fifth, the perfection of meditation, one should concentrate one's mind and not be negligent;

These are the six matters, the basis for bodhisattvas seeking the Way.

There are also six matters - first, eyes; second, ears; third, nose; fourth, mouth; fifth, body; sixth, mind - if a person wishes to seek the Way and receive blessings, they should guard these six matters.

Guard the eyes and do not be attached to form, guard the ears and do not be attached to sound, guard the nose and do not be attached to smell, guard the mouth and do not be attached to taste, guard the body and do not be attached to smoothness, guard the mind and do not be attached to desire.
This is guarding the six matters.
You should also extinguish three matters.
What are the three?
First, lust, second, anger, third, ignorance.
These are the three poisons.
You should also extinguish five matters.
What are the five?
First, pain and itching, second, thoughts, third, birth and death, fourth, consciousness, fifth, craving.
These are the five aggregates.
There are also six decays.
What are the six decays?

First, the eyes decay due to form, second, the ears decay due to sound, third, the nose decays due to smell, fourth, the mouth decays due to taste, fifth, the body decays due to smoothness, sixth, the mind decays due to dharmas.
These are the six decays.
The five aggregates, six sense faculties, and three poisons combined are the twenty things in the body. They are always in the human body. Practitioners should always cut off these twenty things.
If one cannot restrain these twenty things, one will fall into the category of offenses:
If the six sense faculties are not cut off, one will fall into the eighteen hells;
If the five aggregates are not cut off, one will wander through the five paths;
If the three poisons are not severed, one will enter the three evil paths.

If good men and good women restrain and uphold the precepts, purifying the twenty matters within the body like a mirror removing dust, illuminating inside and out, are there a thousand, a hundred million people in the world who are disciples of the Buddha?
The officer said:
Indeed, there are none.
The king said:
Judging from this, I know that the Buddha's merits are great and lofty, profound and majestic, like the vast ocean that cannot be surpassed!
The officer said to the king:
It is truly as the great king says. It is the fault of the lowly officer for not distinguishing the true from the false. I request to be allowed to send them back.
The king said:
Good.
The officer then bid farewell to the people and allowed them to return. The people then fell from high to low, but suddenly revived and regained their livelihood.
The parents then loaded him in a cart and went to Jetavana to inform the Buddha.

Those who violate the precepts will die, and their souls will wander, following their actions to receive retribution. They will become hungry ghosts, animals, or experience the tortures of hell, being whipped, cut, boiled in cauldrons, or burned.
If they have some remaining meager blessings and are reborn in the heavens, they will be in the sixth demon heaven, with meager blessings and short lives, not receiving the teachings of the Dharma.
Even if they become humans, they will be born as lowly slaves;

or as cows, horses, animals, mules, donkeys, camels, elephants, tigers, lions, birds, beasts, insects, moths, suffering unbearably, for hundreds of kalpas, thousands of kalpas, myriads of kalpas, without liberation.
When born, they will immediately become ill or die.
If reborn as a human, they will be incomplete in six faculties, crippled, deaf, blind, mute, or sickly, suffering such extreme hardships.

Now in this world, there is one person who knows that there is a Buddha in the world, hears the sutras, sees the bhikshu sangha, has a good heart, kind thoughts, respectful and compassionate, abandons the ninety-six kinds of paths and enters the true Dharma, reflects on themselves, and upholds the five precepts to cultivate the ten wholesome deeds and eliminate the ten evil deeds.
